pullRequest.body:
Define the set of representatives under the action of SL(2, ZZ) and give some reduction lemmas that are useful for later proving that SL(2, ZZ) is generated by S, T.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

A general remark: in many declarations `m` and/or `A` can be implicit (`m` can be deduced from the type of `A`, and `A` can be deduced from conditions on `A` when present).
To avoid the "Post PR summary comment / ..." error, merge master.
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

Thanks!

bors merge

bors r-

sorry, I was a bit slow with my review
Canceled.

@CBirkbeck I created a branch with several suggestions: #19545 
Please take from this what you like.
Thanks for all the suggestions! I've incorporated basically everything and made a few little changes.
So any other comments on this?

Modulo a minor naming issue, this looks good to me now.

maintainer delegate?

Modulo a minor naming issue, this looks good to me now.

maintainer delegate?

```suggestion
  simpa only [Int.reduceNeg, Fin.isValue, cons_mul, Nat.succ_eq_add_one, Nat.reduceAdd, empty_mul,
    Equiv.symm_apply_apply, vecMul_cons, vecHead, cons_val_zero, zero_smul, vecTail,
    Function.comp_apply, Fin.succ_zero_eq_one, cons_val_one, cons_val_fin_one, neg_smul, one_smul,
    empty_vecMul, add_zero, zero_add, of_apply, cons_val', Pi.neg_apply, vecMul, cons_dotProduct,
    zero_mul, one_mul, dotProduct_empty, mul_comm, mul_neg, â† Int.sub_eq_add_neg,
    â† Int.emod_def (A.1 0 0) (A.1 1 0), empty_val',
    abs_eq_self.mpr (Int.emod_nonneg (A.1 0 0) (abs_ne_zero.mp h))]
  using Int.emod_lt (A.1 0 0) (abs_ne_zero.mp h)
```

```suggestion
  Â· exact h0 _ h
```

```suggestion
    exact reduce_aux m A h
```

```suggestion
def reduce : Î” m â†’ Î” m := fun A â†¦
  if |(A.1 1 0)| = 0 then
    if  0 < A.1 0 0 then (T ^ (-(A.1 0 1/A.1 1 1))) â€¢ A else
      (T ^ (-(-A.1 0 1/ -A.1 1 1))) â€¢ ( S â€¢ ( S â€¢ A)) --the -/- don't cancel with â„¤ divs.
  else
    reduce (reduce_step m A)
  termination_by b => Int.natAbs (b.1 1 0)
  decreasing_by
      next a h =>
      zify
      exact reduce_aux m _ h
```
`by` and `exact` cancel out.

```suggestion
  simp only [abs_eq_zero, zpow_neg, Int.ediv_neg, neg_neg] at *
```

```suggestion
  simp only [zpow_neg, Int.ediv_neg, neg_neg] at *
```

```suggestion
  simp only [zpow_neg, Int.ediv_neg, neg_neg] at *
```

```suggestion
private lemma A_c_eq_zero (A : Î” m) (ha : A.1 1 0 = 0) : A.1 0 0 * A.1 1 1 = m := by
  simpa only [det_fin_two, ha, mul_zero, sub_zero] using A.2

private lemma A_d_ne_zero (A : Î” m) (ha : A.1 1 0 = 0) (hm : m â‰  0) : A.1 1 1 â‰  0 :=
  right_ne_zero_of_mul (A_c_eq_zero m A ha â–¸ hm)

private lemma A_a_ne_zero (A : Î” m) (ha : A.1 1 0 = 0) (hm : m â‰  0) : A.1 0 0 â‰  0 :=
  left_ne_zero_of_mul (A_c_eq_zero m A ha â–¸ hm)
```

```suggestion
  have h1 : 0 < |A.1 1 1| := abs_pos.mpr (A_d_ne_zero m A h.left hm)
  have h2 : 0 < |A.1 0 0| := abs_pos.mpr (A_a_ne_zero m A h.left hm)
```
Where did these convoluted expressions come from?
That was from using `show_term`

```suggestion
  Â· simp only [â† A_c_eq_zero m A h.1, Fin.zero_eta, Finset.mem_Icc, abs_mul]
```

```suggestion
      exact (neg_le_abs (A.1 0 0)).trans ((le_mul_iff_one_le_right h2).mpr h1)
    Â· exact (le_abs_self (A.1 0 0)).trans ((le_mul_iff_one_le_right h2).mpr h1)
```

```suggestion
  Â· simp only [Fin.zero_eta, Fin.mk_one, Finset.mem_Icc]
```

```suggestion
      exact (le_abs_self (A.1 0 1)).trans <| h.2.2.2.le.trans (le_mul_of_one_le_left h1.le h2)
```

```suggestion
  Â· simp only [Fin.mk_one, Fin.zero_eta, h.1, Finset.mem_Icc, Left.neg_nonpos_iff, abs_nonneg,
      and_self]
  Â· simp only [Fin.mk_one, â† A_c_eq_zero m A h.1, abs_mul, Finset.mem_Icc]
```

```suggestion
      exact (neg_le_abs (A.1 1 1)).trans ((le_mul_iff_one_le_left h1).mpr h2)
    Â· exact (le_abs_self (A.1 1 1)).trans ((le_mul_iff_one_le_left h1).mpr h2)
```

```suggestion
  refine Set.eq_empty_iff_forall_not_mem.mpr fun A h â†¦ ?_
  obtain âŸ¨hâ‚, hâ‚‚, -, hâ‚„âŸ© := Set.mem_setOf.mpr h
  simp only [eq_zero_of_ne_zero_of_mul_left_eq_zero hâ‚‚.ne' <| A_c_eq_zero 0 _ hâ‚, abs_zero] at hâ‚„
  exact ((abs_nonneg _).trans_lt hâ‚„).false
```

```suggestion
    simp only [Subtype.mk.injEq, Prod.mk.injEq] at h
    obtain âŸ¨_, _, _, _âŸ© := h
    fin_cases i <;> fin_cases j <;> assumption
```

```suggestion
  by_cases hk : k = 0
  Â· rw [hk, reps_zero_empty]
    exact Set.fintypeEmpty
```
and then remove the second branch below.

```suggestion
  Â· exact fun A h1 h2 â†¦ reduce_eqn3 m A h1 â–¸ h2
```
You should not use the automatically generated lemma `reduce_eqn3` by name. It is better to state the result explicitly (with a suitable name) and prove it by `rfl`, so that it can then be used with a reasonable name. (Similarly for `reduce_eqn1` and `reduce_eqn2` that are used in the `simp only` calls above.)
`Fin.is_value` is not needed in the `simp only` calls. The lines after `simp only` that belong to the same call should be indented by 2 extra spaces (this is a bug in `simp?`).

```suggestion
      Â· simp only [abs_eq_zero.mp h, mul_zero, h1]
```

```suggestion
      Â· exact Int.ediv_mul_le _ <| A_d_ne_zero m A (abs_eq_zero.mp h) hm
```

```suggestion
      Â· rw [mul_comm, â† Int.sub_eq_add_neg, â† Int.emod_def]
        apply le_trans _ (Int.emod_lt (A.1 0 1) (A_d_ne_zero m A (abs_eq_zero.mp h) hm))
        rw [abs_eq_self.mpr (Int.emod_nonneg (A.1 0 1) (A_d_ne_zero m A (abs_eq_zero.mp h) hm))]
```
... and similarly below.

It might also make sense to give things like `A_d_ne_zero m A (by simpa using h) hm` that are used several times a name and use that instead.
I think that having those extra versions might be overkill, so instead I just left the version thats used the most (the one with `abs`).

```suggestion
lemma S_smul_four (A : Î” m) : S â€¢ S â€¢ S â€¢ S â€¢ A = A := by
```

```suggestion
lemma T_S_rel (A : Î” m) : S â€¢ S â€¢ S â€¢ T â€¢ S â€¢ T â€¢ S â€¢ A = Tâ»Â¹ â€¢ A := by
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
  rw [â† S_smul_four m B]
  exact hS _ (hS _ (hS _ ih))
```

```suggestion
  have h := hS _ <| hS _ <| hS _ <| hT _ <| hS _ <| hT _ <| hS _ ih
  rwa [T_S_rel m B] at h
```

```suggestion
  simpa only [inv_smul_smul] using prop_red2 _ hS hT (T â€¢ B) ih
```

```suggestion
    convert hT _ h using 1
    simp only [zpow_neg, zpow_natCast, smul_def, coe_inv, coe_pow, adjugate_pow, â† mul_assoc, â†
      coe_mul, mul_inv_cancel T, one_mul]
```
The condition `A.1 0 0 * A.1 1 1 = m` is unnecessary, I think; it should follow from `A.prop` and the first condition.

```suggestion
    exact h0 _ H1 (A_c_eq_zero _ _ H1) H2 H3 H4
```

```suggestion
      exact prop_red4 _ hS hT A (-(A.1 0 1 / A.1 1 1))
```

```suggestion
      exact fun h â†¦ prop_red1 _ hS _ <| prop_red1 _ hS _ (prop_red4 _ hS hT _ _ h)
```

```suggestion
  exact prop_red4 _ hS hT _ _ <| prop_red1 _ hS _ (ih hA)
```

```suggestion
    next a h =>
    zify
    exact reduce_aux h
```
I would think (see `reduce_rec` above).

```suggestion
  suffices |A.1 i j| â‰¤ |m| from Finset.mem_Icc.mpr <| abs_le.mp this
  have h1 : 0 < |A.1 1 1| := abs_pos.mpr (A_d_ne_zero (abs_eq_zero.mpr h.left) hm)
  have h2 : 0 < |A.1 0 0| := abs_pos.mpr (A_a_ne_zero h.left hm)
  fin_cases i <;> fin_cases j
  Â· simpa only [Fin.zero_eta, â† A_c_eq_zero h.1, abs_mul]
    using (le_mul_iff_one_le_right h2).mpr h1
  Â· simpa only [Fin.zero_eta, Fin.mk_one, â† A_c_eq_zero h.1, abs_mul]
    using h.2.2.2.le.trans (le_mul_of_one_le_left h1.le h2)
  Â· simp only [Fin.mk_one, Fin.isValue, Fin.zero_eta, h.1, abs_zero, abs_nonneg]
  Â· simpa only [Fin.mk_one, â† A_c_eq_zero h.1, abs_mul] using (le_mul_iff_one_le_left h1).mpr h2
```
Going via the absolute value makes this easier, because there is some API available.

```suggestion
    let H4 := Fin 2 â†’ Fin 2 â†’ H
    apply Fintype.ofInjective (Î² := H4)
      (f := fun (M : reps k) â†¦ fun i j â†¦ âŸ¨M.1.1 i j, reps_entries_le_m' hk M.2 i jâŸ©)
    intro M N h
    ext i j
    simpa only [Subtype.mk.injEq] using congrFunâ‚‚ h i j
```
Using the matrix structure `Fin 2 â†’ Fin 2 â†’ ...` seems more natural here.

```suggestion
    have hd := A_d_ne_zero h hm
    by_cases h1 : 0 < A.1 0 0
    focus simp only [reduce_of_pos h h1]
    swap
    focus simp only [reduce_of_not_pos h h1]
    swap
    all_goals
      simp only [reps, zpow_neg, Set.mem_setOf_eq, coe_inv, coe_T_zpow, adjugate_fin_two_of,
        neg_zero, cons_mul, Nat.succ_eq_add_one, Nat.reduceAdd, empty_mul, Equiv.symm_apply_apply,
        of_apply, cons_val', vecMul, cons_dotProduct, vecHead, one_mul, vecTail, dotProduct_empty,
        Function.comp_apply, Fin.succ_zero_eq_one, neg_mul, add_zero, zero_mul, zero_add, mul_zero,
        empty_val', cons_val_fin_one, cons_val_one, cons_val_zero, le_add_neg_iff_add_le, lt_neg,
        Int.ediv_neg, neg_neg, smul_def, â† mul_assoc, S_mul_S_eq, mul_neg, neg_of, neg_cons,
        neg_empty, Pi.neg_apply, neg_add_rev, abs_neg, â† le_neg, abs_eq_zero.mp h, true_and]
    Â· refine âŸ¨h1, Int.ediv_mul_le _ hd, ?_âŸ©
      rw [mul_comm, â† Int.sub_eq_add_neg, â† Int.emod_def, abs_eq_self.mpr <| Int.emod_nonneg _ hd]
      exact Int.emod_lt _ hd
    Â· refine âŸ¨?_, Int.ediv_mul_le _ hd, ?_âŸ©
      Â· simp only [Int.lt_iff_le_and_ne]
        exact âŸ¨not_lt.mp h1, A_a_ne_zero (abs_eq_zero.mp h) hmâŸ©
      Â· rw [mul_comm, add_comm, â† Int.sub_eq_add_neg, â† Int.emod_def,
         abs_eq_self.mpr <| Int.emod_nonneg _ hd]
        exact Int.emod_lt _ hd
```
Trying to write this a bit more compactly (and making use of the fact that both branches are quite similar).

```suggestion
noncomputable instance repsFintype (k : â„¤) : Fintype (reps k) := by
```
(Or `fintypeReps`.) `Fintype` is not a `Prop`, so I think the naming convention calls for lower snake case here.

```suggestion
  rw [abs_ne_zero] at h
  suffices ((reduce_step A).1 1 0) = A.1 0 0 % A.1 1 0 by
    rw [this, abs_eq_self.mpr (Int.emod_nonneg (A.1 0 0) h)]
    exact Int.emod_lt (A.1 0 0) h
  simp_rw [Int.emod_def, sub_eq_add_neg, reduce_step, smul_coe, coe_T_zpow, S]
  norm_num [vecMul, vecHead, vecTail, mul_comm]
```

Why do you want an absolute value in the statement of `h0` and `h1`?
I understand this might be useful for the proof, but is it also the best for applications?
yeah thats a good point, I think its just a leftover from some old stuff. I've updated it now! thanks!

```suggestion
    if 0 < A.1 0 0 then (T ^ (-(A.1 0 1 / A.1 1 1))) â€¢ A else
      (T ^ (-(-A.1 0 1 / -A.1 1 1))) â€¢ (S â€¢ (S â€¢ A)) --the -/- don't cancel with â„¤ divs.
```

```suggestion
    reduce A = (T ^ (-(A.1 0 1 / A.1 1 1))) â€¢ A := by
```

```suggestion
    reduce A = (T ^ (-(-A.1 0 1 / -A.1 1 1))) â€¢ (S â€¢ (S â€¢ A)) := by
```
I think this should be a simp lemma in another file.
